initial_sentence: I sometimes act hastily or seek immediate resolutions when faced with uncertainty, as a way to reduce my anxiety.

chat_history.content: I sometimes act hastily or seek immediate resolutions when faced with uncertainty, as a way to reduce my anxiety.
The priest nods slightly, a calm presence. "Ah, I see, you struggle with impulsivity. You feel anxious if you don't act quickly, is that correct?"

Yeah, it’s like if I don’t figure things out right away, I start feeling this worry creeping in—like I've already failed. I guess I'm just trying to avoid feeling helpless or like I can’t handle things on my own. It's hard when the anxious thoughts start spiraling.

The priest's eyes soften a bit, and he gives a small smile. "Ah, you feel overwhelmed by uncertainty, yes? It is normal to feel uncertain, especially in a world that is so complex and chaotic. However, acting impulsively can often lead to rash decisions that we regret later on. It's natural to want to feel in control, but sometimes we must let go of that feeling and trust in the process."

I suppose that's true—I just fear that letting go might lead me back to being dependent on my parents, which terrifies me. I've worked hard to distance myself from that, but sometimes it feels like walking a tightrope. I don't want to feel like I'm failing at being independent.

The priest listens intently. "Independence is a difficult journey, and it's natural to fear slipping back into old patterns. Relying on your parents may be comfortable, but it's not true independence. True independence means being able to make your own choices and stand on your own two feet, even when it's difficult. It's about building a strong foundation within yourself, rather than relying on others for support."

I know you're right, but it's just hard sometimes when unexpected things happen—like getting this insurance claim I wasn't prepared for. It makes me question if I've really built that strong foundation or if I'm just fooling myself. I'm scared of being seen as a failure, even more so by myself.

"Oh, I understand the frustration and doubt that comes with unexpected challenges. Life has a way of testing our foundation when we least expect it. But remember, everyone faces unexpected situations. The key is to stay resilient and resourceful. You've made progress on building your independence, and facing this claim may be an opportunity for further growth. It's okay to seek help or guidance if you need it. Being scared of failure is natural, but don't let it stop you from taking action. You are capable, just as you are."

Thank you, that's reassuring to hear. It’s hard to remember that setbacks are part of the process and not just proof that I can't handle things. I’ll consider getting some guidance, hopefully without feeling like I’m losing my independence in the process.

It's been... a lot sometimes. I guess I didn't realize how overwhelming these things could be until I was actually in it. Every time I have to deal with bills or something like health insurance, I get so anxious, almost like I'm on the brink of messing it all up.

"It sounds like dealing with bills and health insurance is quite overwhelming for you. I understand that feeling of anxiety and fear of making a mistake. It's normal to feel like you're teetering on the edge when faced with unfamiliar responsibilities. Life has a way of throwing us into situations that can be incredibly stressful, especially when it comes to financial and health matters. Sometimes it's hard to imagine just how difficult certain tasks can be until we're faced with them head-on."

Exactly, and every time something unexpected pops up, like an insurance issue, it feels like proof that I'm not cut out for this. It's exhausting trying to constantly reassure myself that I'm doing okay. I just wish I didn't feel so inadequate all the time.

"It sounds like you feel like every unexpected challenge that comes your way is a reminder of your inadequacy. It's exhausting to constantly reassure yourself, but remember that everyone encounters unexpected obstacles or setbacks. It's okay to feel overwhelmed and inadequate, but it doesn't define your worth as an individual. You are capable and resilient, even when it doesn't feel like it. Be kind to yourself, and give yourself credit for the progress you've made so far."

Thank you for that. I need reminders that it's okay to not have everything figured out right now. Maybe I can try to focus more on the progress I've made instead of just the setbacks. I'll keep trying to handle things without being too hard on myself.

"You are welcome. It's important to acknowledge that not having everything figured out is normal. We are all on continuous journeys of self-discovery and growth. Focusing on your progress and not just your setbacks can help you maintain a positive mindset. Remember to be gentle with yourself and to celebrate the little victories along the way. You've already come a long way, and you're capable of handling whatever comes your way. Keep moving forward and trust in yourself."

I'll try to remember that. It's hard to see the bigger picture when I'm caught up in everything, but I'll work on being kind to myself. I guess it's just about staying patient and trusting the process, even if it's tough at times.

Hi there. Well, I've been working really hard to assert my financial independence ever since I came back from Egypt. But it's been tough, especially when unexpected things like a confusing insurance claim balance pop up. It's like I'm constantly feeling anxious and guilty because I think I should have managed things better, but it still feels like I'm failing.

"Hey there, I can totally understand where you're coming from. It's great that you're trying to assert your financial independence, but dealing with unexpected things like confusing insurance claims balance can be incredibly stressful and overwhelming. It's completely normal to feel anxious and guilty when faced with such challenges, but it's important to remember that setbacks are a natural part of life. You're not failing, you're simply learning and growing. Give yourself some credit for all the progress you've made so far."

Thank you for saying that. I need to remind myself that not everything has to go perfectly for me to still be making progress. It's just that when these issues come up, it feels like all my efforts are being undone. I'll try to focus on the learning aspect instead of just seeing it as a failure.

"You're welcome, and that's a great mindset to have. It's important to remember that progress is rarely linear. Setbacks are inevitable, but it's how you respond to them that matters. Every challenge is an opportunity to learn and grow, and it doesn't negate the progress you've already made. Keep pushing forward, and don't let temporary setbacks define your journey. You're capable of overcoming them, and you're learning and growing stronger with each experience."

I appreciate that perspective, even if it's hard to internalize sometimes. I guess I need to remind myself that facing these challenges means I'm actively working on my independence and that in itself is progress. I'll keep trying to approach each situation as a chance to grow rather than seeing them as signs of failure.

"You're absolutely right. It's understandable that it can be difficult to internalize this perspective, but it's important to remember that facing challenges head-on is a sign of your determination towards financial independence. Every hurdle you overcome is a step towards your goals. Viewing these obstacles as opportunities for growth rather than signs of failure is a healthy mindset to have, and it will propel you forward on your journey. Keep up the great work, you're on the right track."

Thank you, that’s really encouraging to hear. I’m going to try and hold onto that thought when things feel overwhelming. It helps knowing that each challenge is just another step forward, even if it doesn’t feel that way in the moment.

It's been really important to me to handle things on my own because I don't want to rely on my parents, especially when my brother still does. I feel this pressure to prove that I can be independent, but sometimes it's overwhelming. There are moments when I worry about managing everything myself and fear becoming a burden like I perceive my brother to be.
